religions: Protestant 62.8% (Cook Islands Christian Church 49.1%, Seventh-Day Adventist 7.9%, Assemblies of God 3.7%, Apostolic Church 2.1%), Roman Catholic 17%, Mormon 4.4%, other 8%, none 5.6%, no response 2.2% (2011 est.)
national anthem: Te Atua Mou E (To God Almighty)
adopted 1982; as prime minister, Sir Thomas DAVIS composed the anthem; his wife, a tribal chief, wrote the lyrics
industries: fruit processing, tourism, fishing, clothing, handicrafts
legal system: common law similar to New Zealand common law
imports - commodities: foodstuffs, textiles, fuels, timber, capital goods
location: Oceania, group of islands in the South Pacific Ocean, about half way between Hawaii and New Zealand
dependency status: self-governing in free association with New Zealand; Cook Islands is fully responsible for internal affairs; New Zealand retains responsibility for external affairs and defense in consultation with the Cook Islands
literacy: age 15 and over can read and write
exports - commodities: copra, papayas, fresh and canned citrus fruit, coffee; fish; pearls and pearl shells; clothing
diplomatic representation from the us: none (self-governing in free association with New Zealand)
terrain: low coral atolls in north; volcanic, hilly islands in south
geography - note: the northern Cook Islands are seven low-lying, sparsely populated, coral atolls; the southern Cook Islands, where most of the population lives, consist of eight elevated, fertile, volcanic isles, including the largest, Rarotonga, at 67 sq km
political parties and leaders: Cook Islands Party or CIP [Henry PUNA]
Democratic Party or Demo [Dr. Terepai MAOATE]
broadcast media: 1 privately owned TV station broadcasts from Rarotonga providing a mix of local news and overseas-sourced programs; a satellite program package is available; 6 radio stations broadcast with 1 reportedly reaching all of the islands (2009)
constitution: effective 4 August 1965 (Cook islands Constitution Act 1964); amended many times, last in 2004 (2004)
military - note: defense is the responsibility of New Zealand in consultation with the Cook Islands and at its request
capital: UTC-10 (5 hours behind Washington, DC, during Standard Time)
independence: none (became self-governing in free association with New Zealand on 4 August 1965 and has the right at any time to move to full independence by unilateral action)
climate: tropical oceanic; moderated by trade winds; a dry season from April to November and a more humid season from December to March
agriculture - products: copra, citrus, pineapples, tomatoes, beans, pawpaws, bananas, yams, taro, coffee; pigs, poultry
telephone system: Telecom Cook Islands offers international direct dialing, Internet, email, fax, and Telex

individual islands are connected by a combination of satellite earth stations, microwave systems, and VHF and HF radiotelephone; within the islands, service is provided by small exchanges connected to subscribers by open-wire, cable, and fiber-optic cable
country code - 682; satellite earth station - 1 Intelsat (Pacific Ocean)
flag description: blue, with the flag of the UK in the upper hoist-side quadrant and a large circle of 15 white five-pointed stars (one for every island) centered in the outer half of the flag
languages: English (official) 86.4%, Cook Islands Maori (Rarotongan) (official) 76.2%, other 8.3% (2011 est.)
maritime claims: 200 nm or to the edge of the continental margin
area - comparative: 1.3 times the size of Washington, DC
population: the Cook Islands' Ministry of Finance & Economic Management estimated the resident population to have been 13700 in September 2013 (July 2014 est.)
national holiday: Constitution Day, first Monday in August (1965)
diplomatic representation in the us: none (self-governing in free association with New Zealand)
ethnic groups: Cook Island Maori (Polynesian) 81.3%, part Cook Island Maori 6.7%, other 11.9% (2011 est.)
political pressure groups and leaders: Reform Conference (lobby for political system changes)
various groups lobbying for political change
international law organization participa: has not submitted an ICJ jurisdiction declaration (New Zealand normally retains responsibility for external affairs); accepts ICCt jurisdiction
international organization participation: ACP, ADB, AOSIS, FAO, ICAO, ICRM, IFAD, IFRCS, IMO, IMSO, IOC, ITUC (NGOs), OPCW, PIF, Sparteca, SPC, UNESCO, UPU, WHO, WMO
